desc.size: Medium-sized to large tree, 18 - 25 m tall, trunk diameter 40 cm - 1 m. Trunk straight, crown broadly rounded. Sprouts often found at the base of living trees.

part.partText: brown, thick, deeply furrowed into long, narrow, flat-topped, scaly ridges; ridges nearly parallel, sometimes interlacing.
slender, stout, pale reddish brown, somewhat zigzagged, smooth. Leaf scars half-elliptical, with 3 or more bundle scars.
lustrous green or reddish brown, 6 mm long, egg-shaped, pointed, lopsided, smooth. Bud scales usually 2.

alternate, stalked, green and smooth above, densely hairy beneath, 12 - 15 or more cm long, about half as wide, obliquely heart-shaped, lobes unequal, base asymmetrical, tip pointed, margins coarsely toothed, thin, firm.

have both male and female reproductive organs (perfect); borne in drooping clusters on a long, slender stalk attached to a yellowish, paddle-shaped bract; greenish yellow to white, small, hairy, sepals 5, petals 5, fragrant, insect-pollinated.

similarSpecies.comments: The dense coat of hairs on the underside of the leaves distinguishes Tilia americana var. heterophylla from T. americana.

notes.comments: The wood of Tilia americana var. heterophylla is not very durable, but is used for boxes, crates, furniture parts, interior trim, veneer, plywood, pulp, fuel, and hand carving. Although planted as an ornamental, European species are more commonly used. Native Americans made rope from the bark of its young stems.

etymology.comments: Tilia is the Latin name for the linden or basswood tree. Americana means “from America” (North or South). Heterophylla means “diversely leaved.”
